title: Inheritance of Ephraim
shortSummary: Joshua 16 details the boundaries and inheritance allotted to the tribe of Ephraim, one of Joseph's sons, within the Promised Land. It highlights the specific territorial borders and notes the incomplete conquest of the Canaanites in the region, emphasizing the ongoing challenges Israel faced in fully possessing their inheritance.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Division of the Promised Land under Joshua's leadership

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who oversees the allotment of the Promised Land to the tribes.

keyCharacters.name: Ephraim
keyCharacters.description: One of Joseph's sons whose descendants receive a distinct inheritance in the land.

keyCharacters.name: Manasseh
keyCharacters.description: The other son of Joseph, whose territory surrounds some Ephraimite cities.

definitions.definition: A method of casting lots used to fairly divide the land among the tribes of Israel.
The original inhabitants of the land of Canaan, whom the Israelites were commanded to drive out.
A form of payment or service rendered by subjugated peoples, indicating partial submission.
The land and possessions given by God to the tribes of Israel as their rightful possession.

outline.heading: The Boundary of Joseph’s Inheritance
outline.description: This section describes the general borders of the land allotted to the children of Joseph, specifically the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh, setting the stage for the detailed boundaries that follow.

outline.heading: Detailed Borders of Ephraim
outline.description: A precise delineation of Ephraim’s territory is given, outlining the eastern, northern, and western borders, emphasizing the fulfillment of God’s promise through careful division.

outline.heading: Cities Within Ephraim’s Territory
outline.description: This verse notes that some cities belonging to Ephraim were geographically within Manasseh’s inheritance, highlighting the complexity of tribal boundaries.

outline.heading: Incomplete Conquest of the Canaanites
outline.description: The chapter concludes by acknowledging that the Ephraimites did not fully drive out the Canaanites from Gezer, who continued to live among them and pay tribute, illustrating Israel’s partial obedience and the ongoing spiritual and physical challenges.

application: Trust God’s promises and be patient as He fulfills them in His timing, just as the land was allotted according to His plan.
Obedience to God’s commands is essential for fully receiving His blessings; incomplete obedience can lead to ongoing challenges.
Recognize the importance of clear boundaries and stewardship in the responsibilities God entrusts to each believer.
Live in humility and dependence on God, acknowledging that spiritual battles may continue even after initial victories.

keyVerses.text: So the children of Joseph, Manasseh and Ephraim, took their inheritance.
keyVerses.significance: This verse confirms the fulfillment of God’s promise to Joseph’s descendants by allotting them their inheritance.

keyVerses.text: And they drave not out the Canaanites that dwelt in Gezer: but the Canaanites dwell among the Ephraimites unto this day, and serve under tribute.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the consequences of incomplete obedience and the ongoing presence of ungodly influences within Israel.
